Dialogues.content: Woah there, someone is moody!
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Hey, the Santa Cruz beaches have really given you a tan.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Aren't you as chipper as ever!
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Indeed...Well..Glad to have you back!
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Not as much as your mom.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: It's the same but your mom's cooking seems to have gotten worse by the day!
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Yes, I have been doing well but I can't speak for your mom.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Umm sure?? Right Honey?
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: I do things around the house.
Well I need to do everything around the house, so cut me some slack will ya.
I'm doing fine. Don't know what your dad's going on about.
Sure...
What the heck dad?
What are you talking about? Everything is just FINE.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: There is nothing to heck about. Everything is just fine.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: I hope so too.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Nope, nothing going on AT ALL.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Haha! Of course I'm still working - Still doing the same boring thing. I'm not that old yet, you know.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Work's the same' old, same old. There's nothing exciting to say about it.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Haha! Of course I'm still working - Still doing the same broing thing. I'm not that old yet, you know.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Work's the same' old, same old. There's nothing exciting to say about it.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: There is one thing... These cups! These nice and expensive Swarovski crystal cups that your mom brought home about a month ago. These are pretty new.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: It is. There is nothing more like droning work that keeps me motivated. But hey, enough about work, let me tell you about these expensive cups on the table. Your mom brought them home about a month ago. VERY nice, VERY expensive Swarovski crystal cups.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Well, I suppose there is one thing... You see these cups? They're amazing, expensive Swarovski crystal cups your mom brought home.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: New things happen all the time! Just like these month old, nice expensive Swarovski crystal cups your mom brought!
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Thank you. I think they look just awesome, as well.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: Thanks. That means so much to me.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: Sure whatever you think.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: Sure whatever you think.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: You will know that I wish to continue to talk about these cups!

These cups are so refined looking. What else could I say about them? They do look nice, but too bad I was unable to give MY input on whether or not these cups should be purchased. When your Mom brought them home, I was almost shocked. Of course, this isn't a BIG DEAL, so we are just absolutely fine over this whole thing.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Flustered? Hah. Like how you were back in your last year at high school? Do you even remember your high school days? With all that homework and everything, you hardly had time for anything else! I can remember those times, clear as day. Your mom was so engaged, checking in on how you and Alex were doing, listening to me and you kids. And she would be around the house!
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: No! I am being reasonable! And don't say you haven't noticed yet, with- withall of this Swarovski crystal, EIGHT THIRTY dinner nonsense.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: HOW DARE YOU! As a memeber of this house, it is your obligation to be aware of the changes around the house. Swarovski cyrstal, eight thirty dinner...
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: You think so? I can't believe you haven't noticed yet.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: The only thing 'weird' about this is the fact that you haven't noticed yet
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: That's an interesting observation
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: Who knows? I certainly have no idea.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: You can, if you want.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: Who knows? I certainly have no idea.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: Is that so?
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: If you think so, then it must be.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: Is that what you really think?
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: I could.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: Hey! I won’t let you or your Mother ignore me. You shouldn’t let that woman have her way, and let me tell you why!
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Hey! I won’t let you or your Mother ignore me. You shouldn’t let that woman have her way, and let me tell you why!
I knew you were a sensible person. Don’t let this woman have her way. The only thing she’s done for this household is wrong, and let me tell you why.
I knew you were a sensible person. Don’t let this woman have her way. The only thing she’s done for this household is wrong, and let me tell you why.

I honestly can’t believe neither you nor Alex—especially Alex, who has been home the most—haven’t been able to add up all the clues and subtleties to figure it out. Just LOOK at your mom! New hair, new clothes, coming home absolutely reeking of alcohol? It's only obvious!
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: What the hell, Dad! Don't bring me into this shit!

I’m going to ignore your choice of words, for once, because you make a good point. Why should I assume a thankless daughter like you would even care about the sanctity of the home? So, about your Mom...
Didn't I teach you that patience is a virtue? Anyways, what I was going to say is that your mother is cheating on me!
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: There is no need to. I've been waiting for the most appropriate time to say this, but your mom is cheating on me!
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: You know, you’re right. Clearly, your mother is cheating on me.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Yes. It is time now. I've been waiting for the most appropriate time to say this... Your mother is cheating on me!
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: What?.. How could you think that? I'd never do that!
Ha! I'm glad to see that you are thinking rationally and on my side with this!
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: You guess? Hmph! At least you think it makes sense
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Of course everything makes sense! I am not being an idiot about this - your mom might be, but that is besides the point.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: You guess? What 'things' do you need clarification to understand this situation?! It is so simple!
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Very well. I ‘guess’ I’ll spell things out for you, once more. First off, remember those ridiculously expensive cups your Mom came home with? Since I manage both of our finances, she couldn't have possibly afforded those, and even if she did, I would absolutely not let her purchase them! Someone obviously had to get them for her! Your mom never used to go out late, but now she's been coming home at 8:30 and claiming she's been at ‘dinner.’ That's out of the norm!
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: They're not. I bought the glasses myself.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: They're not. I bought the glasses myself.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: No. I bought them myself.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: They're not. I bought the glasses myself.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: Anyone can tell that is an obvious lie! That woman has no way to get Swarvoski crystal glasses by herself!
Cuz  you're a control freak...
You will keep your mouth shut, Alex! Let the adults talk through this!

I will talk to her however I please! You do not have the right to tell me what to do! Anyhow... Back to talking about that ungrateful woman. As the bread maker of this household, I maintain the finances, so there is no way I would let her buy these Swarovski glasses!
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Glad to see you are still able to make sensible decisions. Anyhow... Back to talking about that ungrateful woman. As the bread maker of this household, I maintain the finances, so there is no way I would let her buy these Swarovski glasses!
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Glad to see you are still able to make sensible decisions. Anyhow... Back to talking about that ungrateful woman. As the bread maker of this household, I maintain the finances, so there is no way I would let her buy these Swarovski glasses!
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: No! Alex is just a child. She wouldn't know anything substantiable about what is going in this house. Anyhow... Back to talking about that ungrateful woman. As the bread maker of this household, I maintain the finances, so there is no way I would let her buy these Swarovski glasses!
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: I bought them with my own money. I wanted something a little nice for the house... for myself.
I do. I ... just can't say why.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: I do. I ... just can't say why.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: You've been siding with your Father...
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: That is not the only way ... But I can't say.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: Hmph. There's no point. It's not like you will listen or give me a chance anyways.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: Take a look, DEAR. You have taught the kids a valuable lesson: knowing when to give up. Truly, a job well done.
I'm done with this.
That's hard to believe. You already think I'm cheating on your dad
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: That's hard to believe. You already think I'm cheating on your dad
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: That's hard to believe. You already think I'm cheating on your dad
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: ... Yes, it does. You already think I'm cheating on your dad.

Dialogues.content: That is the only correct answer, logically.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Logically, that is the only correct answer.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: I thought you would be more open to hearing my side, but it doesn't seem like you will be. I don't think there's a point to me sitting at this dining table any longer.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: So you admit to your infidelity!
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: I'm not admitting to anything, but I'll be finishing dinner elsewhere
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: I honestly can’t believe you nor Alex—especially Alex, who has been home the most—haven’t been able to add up all the clues and subtleties to figure it out. Just LOOK at your mom! New hair, new clothes, coming home absolutely reeking of alcohol—It’s only obvious!
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: What the hell, Dad! Don't bring me into this shit!
Dad! What the hell?! Don't bring me into this.

I’m going to ignore your choice of words, for once, because you make a good point. Why should I assume a thankless daughter like you would even care about the sanctity of the home? So about your Mom...
Didn't I teach you that patience is a virtue? Anyways, what I was going to say is that your mother is cheating on me!
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: There is no need to. I've been waiting for the most appropriate time to say this, but your mom is cheating on me!
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: You know, you're right. Clearly your mom is cheating on me!
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Yes. It is time now. I've been waiting for the most appropriate time to say this... Your mother is cheating on me!
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: What?.. How could you think that? I'd never do that!
What do you mean? Of course it does. New hair, late dinners, bringing home expensive dinnerware. You must be blind if you can’t see that this woman is cheating on me!
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: How can you be so nonchalant about all of this! New hair, late dinners, bringing home expensive dinnerware. You should care! You are being ignornat and blind to this whole situation.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Are you just brushing me off? New hair, late dinners, bringing home expensive dinnerware. You should care! You are being ignorant and blind to this whole situation.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: How can you be so uncertain about all of this! New hair, late dinners, bringing home expensive dinnerware. You should care! You are being ignornat and blind to this whole situation.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: These are all normal things I do.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: Then what about the alcohol, hm? Feel free to even TRY and explain that one. On certain days you come home reeking of alcohol. You go seeing other men, grab a couple drinks, and even DARE to come home smelling like that!
I'm not doing that at all. It's just... a coincidence, that's all
Yes. Why don't we hear the whole damn story, hm?
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Hey, stop being so rude to Mom!
Oh, you will see.
All you'll see is how paranoid you've become.
Hah, I bet you can't even explain the alcohol.
My point exactly. It's all gone downhill.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: Yes, I'd love to. It's all gone downhill.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: Please, thank you. It's all gone downhill.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: I was going to say... It's all gone downhill.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: I'd say.
DAD!
And it's precisely due to that attitude. You let that promotion you got last year get to your head!
And what does my hard work have to do with the smell of beer you drag home?
All of you keep ganging up on me! You're all blind! Blind as bats! And you apparently can't smell either.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Wow, slinging names and insults now?
Damn, slinging names and insults now? Wow.
That's what I'm saying. Here's my work ID.
And what's that exactly.
She doesn't have a job! Who do you think you're fooling?
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: What's clear?
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: You're joking, right?
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: You're being very difficult with me.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Yes, that's correct. This is my badge at the Scarlet Space.
Hah! How'd you even manage that? You can't even manage the household finances!
Wow. Rude much?
Rude!
Alex. You are to be quiet. You had your chance to speak.

Beyond help? How dare you! I am not beyond help! It’s all of you who need help—ganging up on me, believing everything your mom says. That nametag or whatever is fake! It’s merely a gimmick and a distraction, trying to cover up her insolence. I'll be finishing dinner elsewhere.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Fine. Let's say the work ID is real. What reason does your Mom have to work? She doesn't manage the family finances. I'm the one who got the promotion at work and brings in all the money.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Fine. Let's say the work ID is real. What reason does your Mom have to work? She doesn't manage the family finances. I'm the one who got the promotion at work and brings in all the money.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Fine. Let's say the work ID is real. What reason does your Mom have to work? She doesn't manage the family finances. I'm the one who got the promotion at work and brings in all the money.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: I can deal with that. I'll be polite and reasonable and let your Mom explain herself.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: It's because of the money.
Do you feel bad about your incompetence? Ha! Are you jealous of the money I am making!
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: …Why can’t you just let me talk for once? The problem is because we have money!
…Don’t assume I’m jealous. What would I be jealous of? But Dad’s promotion IS a problem.
Don't call me incompetent. In a way, yes. The money your dad makes, made me get my job.
Stay quiet for once! Please. Money itself isn’t causing a problem. It’s because it’s your Dad’s money.
How is my hard earned money causing problems?! My money is what puts a roof over our heads, food in our stomachs, clothes on our backs. It's a blessing you're clearly ungrateful for.
Are you calling my efforts a waste? I worked hard for that promotion and the money I make!
How is my hard earned money causing problems?! My money is what puts a roof over our heads, food in our stomachs, clothes on our backs—well, not you. Not you anymore!
No! How dare you! I will not say quiet. You are insulting my hard work and I refuse to stand for this. My money is not problematic! It's a blessing that you are blatantly thankless for.
Can't you see what your dad is doing?
Okay. Yeah, that sounds fair.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: ...Fine. I guess that's fair.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: I suppose I could do that.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: I'll try to explain better
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: Yeah Mom. I live here and I don't even know what you're talking about.
Yeah Mom. I live here and I don't even know what you're talking about.
Yeah Mom. I live here and I don't even know what you're talking about.
Yeah Mom. I live here and I don't even know what you're talking about.
What are you trying to pull...?
What are you trying to pull...?
What are you trying to pull...?
What are you trying to pull...?
What I mean to say is, the money that Dad makes from his promotion is making him controlling.
Controlling? Have you gone mad? I don't force you to do things nor reprimand you going out. Husbands don't own their wives in this country.
Financially, I mean.
Don't be ridiculous, you can't be financially controlling.
That's just me being a caretaker. There isn't anything inherently evil about that. Is your mom upset I don't let her spend money willy-nilly? that's not being controlling; that's being responsible
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Taking care of the house is fine.
Then what is the issue?!

The issue is that you are on a power trip from your work promotion that you can't shut up about. Everything has to be in your silly money bounds! I need to ask you for an allowance and even then you want to know what I'm using it for. I have to stick with your stupid 'fun money' budget when you go out with your coworkers and friends all the time. I don't have any freedom!
because I was waiting for a better time.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: I wasn't holding it in. I Guess I was waiting for an appropriate time.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: I was waiting for a more appropriate time.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: There wasn't a good time.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: Diane, were keeping all this to yourself—not telling me, not communicating with me! What in the Sam Hill were you thinking?! We could have avoided so many frustrations, so much wasted time…
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: I’m sorry, I shouldn’t have done that, but I am not sorry for going out and getting a job! You probably don’t understand what it felt like to find that small bit of freedom.
That might be correct, but that’s no excuse. You know what? I am sorry for accusing you of cheating on me, Diane.
After hearing all this, I suppose that I may have… put rules that are a bit too strict on your Mom. Diane, I am sorry for that also — being so strict that you thought you had to hide things from me.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: I suppose. I may have put a few too many strict rules on the money and your Mom. Diane, I apologize for making you feel so incredibly frustrated—so much that you thought you had to hide things from me.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: You are correct. Diane, I apologize for being stupidly strict and making you feel that you had to hide things from me to get your ounce of freedom.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Hmmm...okay. I have noticed that I may have put rules that are a bit too strict on her. Diane, I am sorry for what I did. I hope you feel that you won’t need to hide things from me anymore.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Okay, Timothy. I accept your apology. Don’t expect me to quit my job though.
Oh, of course. This could all have been avoided. I’m sorry for being too afraid to speak up about this sooner. Don’t expect me to quit my job though.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: What? But you won’t need to work if I become less strict!
I enjoy working! It’s so much more better than staying home all day. It’s actually somewhat relaxing.
Isn’t it better to not work?
That’s coming from someone who is a complete workaholic! Why can’t I work?

Yes, of course. We did take up a lot of time dealing with that cheating nonsense, isn’t that right, Diane? We'll discuss this work situation at a more appropriate time later, and not in front of the whole family.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Of course we will, Timothy.
Another quality bombshell guys, let's change the subject before you guys start ripping each other's head off.
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: *Scoff* is anyone else tired of hearing about you and university?
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: Alex, that is very rude! Be respectful for what you get, even if you don't like it. That is very nice of you dear, I'm sure your sister will like it when she sees it.
I am glad that someone can spend money on the family without being persecuted.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: Some gifts are different than expensive crystal glasses, Diane. I can only guess what your intentions were, but those purchases clearly weren’t meant for us. Not only glasses but fancy haircuts, and dinners from our checking account, too? That doesn’t make it any less incriminating.
This always happens. You guys are so annoying!
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: Alex please don't get involved in this. This isn't meant for you.

You guys always get into screaming matches and it never goes anywhere. Remember when we went to parent-teacher night at school? You guys were at each other's throats the whole time. You embarrassed me in front of the whole school! What were you arguing about anyway?
None of your business, it was about adult things... your mom and I don’t always see eye to eye on things, you know this. You don’t have to know everything that goes on between us.
Kids at school always see me as the kid with the weird family. I can't keep any friends because they fear they'll get yelled at by you guys.
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: Don't brush this off! The kids at school won’t talk to me because they are scared of you guys! They are scared that they’ll get caught in the crossfire of one of your infamous arguments!
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: Kids at school always see me as the kid with the weird family. I can't keep any friends because they fear they'll get yelled at by you guys.
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: Don’t belittle this! The kids at school won’t talk to me because they are scared of you guys! They are scared that they’ll get caught in the crossfire of one of your infamous arguments!
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: That's ridiculous, we would never do that!
You already did! Remember when I brought Janine home so we could work on our book report? She had to go home early because you guys scared her.
I just want what's best for our family and I guess we all have to learn that we can't always get what we want.
*scoff* Whatever.
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: Wow. Look at you guys coming together! In the future, if there is anything you need help with, or any questions at all, we will be here for you Alex.
Well there is one thing that has been nagging at me….
Anything dear, we’re all ears.
I’ve been suspended from school.
What?! Why?
How could this happen!?
Long story, but I have been getting in trouble a lot in school and I have been hiding the notices from you guys.
Alex, I don’t know what to say… In trouble? For what?

Well I was hanging out with some girls at lunch, and some boys came over to us and started acting stupid and annoying us. We asked them to stop but they kept making fun of us. I went over to one of the boys and I pushed him. He fell down some stairs and broke his arm. All of his friends ran to help him and one of the teachers saw me push him so I was sent to the principal's office.
Alex, I’m very disappointed in you! Haven’t we told you to think before you act?
Yes, young lady, your actions have consequences! You’re lucky that that boy’s parents aren't suing us.
I’m sorry, ok! I didn’t mean to break his arm, I just wanted them to stop!

I would have taken them too, I don’t care! He started it and I have to show that I won’t be messed with! It’s not my fault I did what I had to do. I only have 7 days left in my suspension, I guess summer has come early for me this year.
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: I would have taken them too, I don’t care! He started it and I have to show that I won’t be messed with! It’s not my fault I did what I had to do. I only have 7 days left in my suspension, I guess summer has come early for me this year.
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: I’m sorry, I felt threatened and I had to show that I couldn’t be messed with. He started it, he should have known what could have happened. I only have 7 days left in my suspension, I guess summer has come early for me this year.
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: I’m sorry, I felt threatened and I had to show that I couldn’t be messed with. He started it, he should have known what could have happened. I only have 7 days left in my suspension, I guess summer has come early for me this year.
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: No one ever sides with me on these things! He was instigating me and he saw it coming! So what if I miss school? They didn’t want me there, they showed that through the grades they were giving me! For once I just want to go a day where I’m not the punching bag!
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: I don’t need this from you! And Mom and Dad don’t listen to me! I tried be honest with you all, and here we are arguing again. I can’t go five minutes without being the bad guy here...I’ll just leave like you left.
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: I don’t care! I hate you! You always side with Mom and Dad!
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: Admit it! You're obviously the favorite child. Mom and Dad actually likes a kid who does something with their life. You got to succeed while I’m left here to suffer!
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: Admit it! You're obviously the favorite child. Mom and Dad actually likes a kid who does something with their life. You got to succeed while I’m left here to suffer!
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: Just because I’m your sister doesn’t mean I’m not the favorite. Mom and Dad actually like their one kid who actually has done something with their life. You got to succeed while I’m left here to suffer!
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: Admit it! You're obviously the favorite child. Mom and Dad actually likes a kid who does something with their life. You got to succeed while I’m left here to suffer!

Dialogues.content: Why do you have to make this about yourself!
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: Why do you have to make this about yourself!
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: Why do you have to make this about yourself!
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: Why do you have to make this about yourself!

Dialogues.content: Would you even care if I did?
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: it just seems like you're not really putting in an effort to understand Dad's mistakes.

Dialogues.content: If you keep being frustratingly ambiguous, of course we aren't going to care!
Ugh. Ignore Dad, Mom. Even I care, a little bit...
Fine. I will keep my mouth shut for the time being...
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Okay...
Get talking, Mom.
Yes, of course. Well, the money your dad is bringing in because of the promotion has been making him so controlling.

Making blatant accusations? How uncouth...I am not being controlling, I never have been. Like I said before, the only thing I control in this house are the finances. I do not tell your mom how she has to live her life.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: That is wrong! I am not controlling! I don’t tell your mom how she has to live her life.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: No, she does not mean it, because she is wrong! I never have been controlling. I do not tell your mom how she has to live her life.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: That’s correct. I am not controlling. How does your mom even come up with these things… Anyways, no! I have never been controlling. I do not tell your mom how she has to live her life.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Financially, I mean! Y-you make me ask you for an allowance. An ALLOWANCE. I'm your WIFE, not some child. And you insist on knowing how I spend every cent of it. I need to stay within your ‘fun money’ budget, when you go out with your friends and coworkers all the time. With you breathing down my neck all the time, so damn concerned about money, I don’t have any space to have fun or get any freedom.

That’s because you are limiting yourself too hard, Diane. You shouldn’t see the allowance or budget as a way of me controlling you. You should see them as a way to make sure there is order in the household.
Order? Your ‘order’ made me go out and get a job and hide it from you so I could know what it felt like to have the independence I had before your stupid promotion!
You know what? Have it your way. I’ll let your Mom keep her job.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: I’ve been taught to never be lazy and find the ‘easiest’ way to do things, but I can make an exception. I’ll let your Mom keep her so-called job.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Don’t be an idiot. Happiness is not something to guarantee. Even with reclaimed independence, will your Mom actually be? Who knows, but I suppose I’ll let her keep her job.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: And your Mom was worried about you being on my side… Hmph. I could let your Mom keep her 'job,' but I refuse to admit I am being controlling or change my ways because as the caretaker of this household, I know what is for the best.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Let me? Even if you didn’t ‘let me,’ I would keep my job. Why can’t you just admit your faults? Nothing gets through your thick, fat skull, Timothy.
Ridiculing me is going to get you nowhere. Has your new found ‘independence’ made you lose your civility?

You know what? Thank you. Thank you for giving me the life I’ve always wanted. And you want me to be civil? Then I will be! I am so sorry for going behind your back and getting a job and accusing you of being controlling. You are just doing your best for the family, after all.

Good. Well, I accept your apology, and will go ahead and forgive you. And how about we blame all that cheating nonsense on your trivial bartending job? It’s probably all the stress that got to you. Right, Diane?
What—how are you blaming me for something you caused? Sure. Okay. Yes, that sounds like a great idea, Timothy.
I don't like that tone young lady. Do you want to get sent to your room?
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: *Mumbling*Stupid..*mumbling* Hate you..
That's it! Go to your room! You can come out when you learn to show some respect for your family.
Oh my god! I hate you so much!
I'm sorry, dear. Your sister hasn't been the same since you left. I thought it was just the puberty, but I never thought it would be this bad.
Let's hope. I just don't know how to reach her anymore. We used to get along really well, but since you left, her grades slipped and I started losing her.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Didn't help that you kep her enrolled in the Girl Scouts when she clearly didn't want to do it.
Girls Scouts breeds dependable, responsible, and well-mannered young girls. I was in the Boy Scouts when I was a kid, same with my dad, and his before him, and look how I turned out.
Right..

I kept her in it because it is what is right for her. She needs to learn for herself the lifestyle that will bring her success. Some stupid soccer or dancing classes won’t get her into university or become an upstanding citizen.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Oh boy are those Samoas are my Achilles' Heel. I always gain a few pounds when cookie season comes around. She seems to get along with the other girls in her troupe and I want her to learn some fundamentals behind living in the real world. She won’t get that with some soccer or dancing lessons, I’ll tell you that.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: I kept her in it because it is what is right for her. She needs to learn for herself the lifestyle that will bring her success. Some stupid soccer or dancing classes won’t get her into university or become an upstanding citizen.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: I kept her in it because it is what is right for her. She needs to learn for herself the lifestyle that will bring her success. Some stupid soccer or dancing classes won’t get her into university or become an upstanding citizen.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: If I remember correctly she did like the drama class she took last year. Maybe we should see if there are any drama clubs or youth groups she could join. She might like it.

There is no way my daughter is going in some tooty fruity acting class. She needs to grow up, put her emotions aside and hit the books. She’ll grow up to be a famous scientist or engineer one day, and carry on the family’s legacy. She won’t get anywhere with theatre.

It isn’t that easy anymore. When she applies for colleges they'll be looking at what classes she took and how well she did in them. Even if she does well in the artsy classes, the science classes are what will get her farther. Even then, it’s all familiarity when it comes to science classes. The more she sees it and applies herself, the easier it will be for her in highschool and college. I can tell she isn’t applying herself at all this year. I’ve been discovering tests that she has been trying to throw away. She’s failing both her Biology and History classes. I don’t know how we didn’t figure this out sooner.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Why didn’t you tell me about this? I don't see you contributing anything to helping her succeed with her schoolwork.
I have tried lending her my help but everytime she says that she doesn’t want it. I don’t know how to reach that girl, maybe this new college grad can show off some newly garnered expertise.
You don’t have to do that, honey. Your father just likes to take some responsibility off of himself. Tim, you need to help Alex with her homework, don’t sell one of our children out to the other.

I don’t do that. I was simply acknowledging the achievement that our child has accomplished. Have you heard what I have been saying? Alex is failing school, I have tried to help her but she obviously doesn’t value my help. Last time I checked, there are two college educated people under this roof, and she obviously only respects one of them and it isn't me. Instead of casting blame, do you want to help Alex, Diane? I’m sure you learned some things with your high school diploma.

I don’t do that. I was simply acknowledging the achievement that our child has accomplished. Have you heard what I have been saying? Alex is failing school, I have tried to help her but she obviously doesn’t value my help. Last time I checked, there are two college educated people under this roof, and she obviously only respects one of them and it isn't me. Instead of casting blame, do you want to help Alex, Diane? I’m sure you learned some things with your high school diploma.

I don’t do that. I was simply acknowledging the achievement that our child has accomplished. Have you heard what I have been saying? Alex is failing school, I have tried to help her but she obviously doesn’t value my help. Last time I checked, there are two college educated people under this roof, and she obviously only respects one of them and it isn't me. Instead of casting blame, do you want to help Alex, Diane? I’m sure you learned some things with your high school diploma.

I don’t do that. I was simply acknowledging the achievement that our child has accomplished. Have you heard what I have been saying? Alex is failing school, I have tried to help her but she obviously doesn’t value my help. Last time I checked, there are two college educated people under this roof, and she obviously only respects one of them and it isn't me. Instead of casting blame, do you want to help Alex, Diane? I’m sure you learned some things with your high school diploma.
Some of us had the luxury of finishing college, while others had to take care of our children. Just because I didn’t finish college, doesn’t mean I didn’t want to.
Honey, it was not your fault. You and your sister were the best things to happen to me. Having kids changes your life for better, or for worse. It’s just how you see it.

That’s right. We’re both very happy that you’re in our lives. Your mother had you at the end of her third year at university right when I was finishing up. Your mother tried her hardest to support you while getting through school, but it didn’t work out in the end. There’s always the future; you could go back to school and finish the degree.

Where were you again? Oh yeah that’s right. While I was slaving away through school, you were off with your mates enjoying your graduation vacation. I never got the whole story of what happened that summer.
Oh that trip. I hardly remember it, it mustn't have been that eventful. *gulp*. But look what we have to show for all that hard work: a bright college graduate! Cheers everybody!
Don’t talk to me like that! We were young and naive. I wasn’t thinking clearly.
We were young and naive. I was carried away with just graduating college. I wasn’t thinking clearly.
I’m afraid it is true, sweetie. I was carried away with graduating college, and I wanted to get away.
I’m afraid it is true, sweetie. I was carried away with graduating college, and I wanted to get away.

You spent half of our savings on booze and god-knows-what when you left. That money was saved for getting me through college and for the baby. You “getting away” from it all cost us more than you realized.

I spent the money knowing I had a pretty cushy job lined up right when I got back. I’m sorry I put your dreams at risk with my actions, but I did it because our lives were going to change for the better. We were going to live the good life. Can’t a man get away with trying to provide for his family?

I can’t believe I’m hearing this right now. I had to put my future on hold to deal with both our problems, while you completely forsaken yours. Do you really think your job gave us a better life? Sure, it gave us money, but did that money make us any happier or closer as a family? I dreamed of being a part of a happy family while supporting it; however, all my hopes were crushed because of that summer. ‘Also providing for the family’? It’s like I’m listening to a broken record.

Honey, when you’re that young, you don’t think about the ramifications of having a kid. You may have come at an unfortunate time, but this doesn't mean we love you any less. At least I don't, anyway. Like I said before, you were the best thing to happen to us, regardless of the timing. I’m just glad you didn’t go down the same road that we did. You were always the smart one, after all.
I’m sorry, both of you… I…

I don’t need your apology, your kids need to know what you really are. Did you really think that putting your desires over our family would lead us to happiness? I've been a cog in your machine for a while, and now the kid have to live under your control. Out of all of us, Alex is the one feeling the most pressure from you right now. If anyone needs an apology it’s her. <> Alex! Can you come in here please?
Alex, honey, we’ve been doing a lot of talking, and I think your father wants to say something.

Alex,honey, I’m so sorry I’ve been hard on you. I was trying to do what I thought was right but got carried away and ignored what was actually happening. Since this is all on the floor now, and it’s a lot to take in, I want to be frank with you. I love all of you, and I don’t want to be the bad guy anymore.
I guess I can be more honest with you guys.
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: I guess I can be more honest with you guys.
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: Thanks Dad, I needed to hear that. I’ve been doing some thinking and I’ve decided to be more honest with you and Mom.
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: I guess I can be more honest with you guys.
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: Even after all those things I said about you, you still want to help me?
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: That’s true! We want to help you, but you keep shutting us out! Look, we can sit here all night and berate you about what you have done, but that won’t fix what has already happened. We need to focus on how you’re going to deal with what you have started yourself. And you, Alex, need to own up to your actions and work with us. Our advice only goes as far as you’re willing to take it.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: I guess I have been pretty uncooperative with you guys. I always feel like anything I do I get in trouble for.
We’re here to help you, and your father and I will support you. We’re in this together we just need to see some action taken on your part.
It does! I’m sorry for what I've done, and I want to be a better person. I guess the first step was not only being honest with you guys, but also with myself.
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: Thank you for believing in me! After all I have said and done, I am glad that my family is still standing beside me!
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: I’m glad to see you two coming together again! You guys keep this family together and we’re stronger when we enjoy each other’s company. I’m glad that you've finally taken some control over your situation. You remind me of myself when I was in college. I made some mistakes along the way, and didn't acknowledge them until they started piling up. Once it became too much for me to handle on my own, I had to rely on my own mother to put everything in perspective for me. Luckily, we’re having this conversation now and not waiting for the consequences to be more serious.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: Wow Mom, I didn’t know you’ve been through what I have been.

Everyone has at different points of their life, Alex. It just depends on how they deal with them. Even though it doesn’t seem like it, you’re lucky to have a family that is willing to support you through it. I’m sorry for not sticking up for you sooner. I was afraid you guys would despise me for keeping these secrets from the family, but I’m glad I don’t have to worry anymore.
I’m happy for you Diane, and I’m glad that my honesty brought everyone together. If it wasn’t for me, we would still be all bickering.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: I agree, we have been through a lot today as a family. If it wasn’t for my honesty, we would all still be bickering.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Yeah honey, I’m impressed that you had the courage to admit that. I’m glad that we are finally having this conversation and I’m sure that my honesty cleared things up as well.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Yeah honey, I’m impressed that you had the courage to admit that. I’m glad that we are finally having this conversation and I’m sure that my honesty cleared things up as well.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: If I remember correctly, your “honesty” was to criticize Alex and myself.
Right, but I did it out of love. I’m trying to do what was right for the family by being honest about my faults.
I see that, I’m just saying that I wasn’t the emotional one here. If I remember correctly my confession came from a place of keeping the family functional. There has to be due process right?
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: I see that, I’m just saying that I wasn’t the emotional one here. If I remember correctly my confession came from a place of keeping the family functional. There has to be due process right?
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Well, I wasn’t the emotional one here. There has to be due process right? If I remember correctly, my confession came from a place of keeping the family functional.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Well, I wasn’t the emotional one here. There has to be due process right? If I remember correctly, my confession came from a place of keeping the family functional.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Honey, I know you like to keep your pride, but this isn’t the fight you want to win right now.
I can’t believe you, Dad.

Don’t make me laugh. We all know your sister is a lost cause. Instead of ridiculing me and defending your mom, you should learn your place. Do you really think you can walk in here with that shiny, new diploma and decide what is best for your sister? How sophomoric of you.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: You can’t get anywhere in the world by just being ‘nice’. Can’t take any constructive criticism? You’re just as bad as your brainless little sister.
Really, Mom? I come back and this is how you treat me? No 'Welcome back, Alex!' or 'Are you feeling better?'
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: I come back and this is how you treat me? No 'Welcome back, Alex!' or 'Are you feeling better?'
In case you forgot, you did leave dramatically. Do you really expect us to be accommodating?
I am acting as a parent should! I can’t promote such negative behavior at the dinner table! How could you put me in the same boat as your dad?
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: I thought you wanted me at the dinner table. I didn’t come back here to deal with more of this BS!

There is nothing going on! I just came to the realization that what your dad said is true. There isn’t going to be any progress if we’re nice to each other all the time. It’s like cleaning-- it’s not fun, and you have to put some backbone in it to make sure the stubborn spots are scrubbed away.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: There’s nothing going on. I disagreed at the time, but I agree with your father now. Thanks to your dad, I see that being nice isn’t going to get our family anywhere. We need to be strict! It’s like cleaning, you know? We can’t leave dirty spots around, even if they can be a bit stubborn.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: Alex may be having a hard time, but I don’t think being nice is going to improve this situation. It’s just like your Dad said. When you clean, do you leave tiny spots around just because they’re a bit stubborn? No! You put in some elbow grease and scrub them out.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: I’m not being mean. I’m being stern. Your conversation with your dad made me realize that perhaps being nice isn’t the way to solve this problem. You know how when you clean, you always come across a stubborn little spot? You don’t ever leave it there. You scrub it out with some tough elbow grease!
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: Are you seriously comparing me to some damn spot that needs to be scrubbed away? What kind of shitty analogy is that!
Well, actually, it is a great analogy. Well done, Diane. I take back my snarky comment about you only being a high school graduate. In that moment, I had forgotten about how bright you truly are.
Thank you dear, that means a lot. And Alex? You will watch your language.

We have our senses. You should realize the way you’re treating Alex isn’t going to help improve her behavior at all…. Hmph. With the way you’re acting now, I think we should be more stern with you too. Maybe that way you’ll hurry up and find a job and stop being so soft on Alex.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: Our acts are 'brushed up.' We are already treating Alex as we should, and perhaps we should treat you similarly as well. Maybe that way you’ll hurry up and find a job and stop being so soft on Alex.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: Don’t be silly. Alex WILL stay at the dinner table whether she likes it or not, or else there will consequences … There’s no need for further discussion. Being stern with Alex is the best way for me and your father to help her, and it looks like it might be the best way to help you too. Perhaps that way, you’ll hurry up and find a job and stop being so soft on Alex.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: Figure out? You’re so silly. There isn’t anything we need to figure out. We are treating Alex as we should and I think we should treat you the same way. Maybe that way you’ll hurry up and find a job and stop being so soft on Alex.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: ...is this really happening?
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: I guess I’m surprised that Mom actually agrees with Dad, even after all the cheating bullshit that happened. I mean, Mom always tried to argue for me, saying that I should be able to do the stuff that I like. Now she’s saying Now she’s saying I’m just some stupid speck of dust...
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: I don’t need to you to talk! I can make my own space...but thanks, I guess. But, uh. Yeah, you’re right. It’s weird that Mom thinks being strict is the way to go since she just argued with dad about it. I can’t believe she called me a piece of dirt.
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: Heh, yeah. I guess I usually do… I guess I’m just surprised Mom agrees with Dad even after spending so much time arguing about how I should do what I want. And now I’m just considered dirt to both of them? I’m kinda...having a hard time dealing with this.
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: Well, yeah. Mom just called be a piece of dirt… I thought she actually cared about me doing the things that I want and not being so stressed out. I mean, she and Dad argued so much, but I guess that was just some gross power play thing they were doing.
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: Ha! With Alex quiet, this will be the best time to bring down my regular discipline plan on her

No, Alex. You’re wrong—Dad and I couldn’t expect you to understand, but we are doing this for you. It’s time for you to shape up. Don’t expect us to allow you to hang out with your friends anymore, unless you learn how to be respectful and bring your grades up. As for you, our dear college grad...how dare you talk back to us! You should know that strict discipline is the only way to become successful in this world.
Th-that is not Dad’s fault! Don’t blame him for your weakness!
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: How dare you! Who gave you the right to speak about me that way? If you shaped up your act, you would be out in the world making money at some shiny new job, not here lazing around at home! Your Mom is correct. You’re pathetic—I don’t even know why we invited you to move back in after graduation.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: You’re being ridiculous, there’s nothing to congratulate you for! You have accomplished nothing an adult your age should have by now. You contribute nothing to this house and you’re just as hopeless as Alex. You’re just a curse to this family there’s no reason we should be grateful for you being home.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: There is nothing to congratulate you for! You’ve accomplished nothing compared to other people your age. You contribute nothing to this house and you’re just as hopeless as Alex. You’re just a curse to this family, there’s no reason we should be grateful for you being home.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Anyone can do that, but the fact that you aren’t getting results proves you’re talentless and useless.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: You’re completely right, we don’t want you here at all. We wouldn’t have had to deal with any of these problems if you hadn’t decided to show up.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Can’t you see your dad and I are like this because the two of you are hopeless? We’re exhausted. We can’t get a break-- we go to work and get stressed, and come home to deal with this nonsense. Oh my goodness… I—I think the stress is finally getting to me. I feel light headed…
What the hell are you talking about, Mom? You said your job was therapeutic! Oh my god. Quit this bullshi! You aren’t fooling anyone with your stupid acting!
Look at your poor Mother! It’s okay Diane, these pathetic children don’t know what’s coming for them.
No children of mine would cause my life so much distress! The house would be so much more peaceful without the two of you here.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: YOU ARE SICK AND DISGUSTING. You don’t even see us as your kids anymore? Mom, what about?!
You are making me very uncomfortable.

Ha! You feel uncomfortable? At least you don’t feel like a hated piece of trash! Why are you so selfish. You went out and got a job and bought those stupid cups because all you thought about was yourself! You are a selfish...selfish BITCH.
You’re not joking, are you? We’re actually going to leave this house?
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: Nonsense! You’re too much of a coward to pull something like that!
Good riddance!
Yeah, YEAH. Let’s go! We don’t need Dad- I mean, Tim, or- or Diane! They don’t know what’s best for us anyways when they abandoned us long ago.
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: I bet you won’t make it for a month before crawling back here! But by all means, go! Just remember that you both left because you were weak. We don’t need your kind here.
We’ll finally be able to have peace and quiet...and maybe after you leave, you’ll learn to appreciate how such good parents we are.
Have you thought about the financial burden I've had to endure?! Don’t forget about keeping your ass in college. You guys don’t realize but you need a lot to be comfortable.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Well if you let me get my job then we could have shared the financial burden. I guess you don’t like me being financially sufficient.
I didn’t say that. I was merely condemning your spending habits. Spending a lot of money on superfluous glassware is not something we do.

Oh my god! I thought we got through this argument ten minutes ago! We’re here to listen to Alex and become closer as a family! What ever happened to being honest with each other and being respectful of everyone's mistakes?
I am trying to be honest, everyone else is admitting to their mistakes but you don’t seem to be remorseful for your excessive spending habits.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Dad, can we talk about something else…
Alex, don’t get involved. This is an adult matter that doesn't concern you. So what exactly was your job again?
What...? Are you serious?
A simple question. What was your job title?
You really think I’m cheating on you? *snicker* <> Fine. Cashier.
That’s it?
And I mop from time to time.
Jared, our neighbor’s kid; he works there too right?
You really think I would cheat on you with a college kid?! What kind of sick mind do you have!? You think I would do that and put my family at risk?
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: Can you please stop talking about this? The imagery is killing me.
You haven’t denied it yet Diane. I’m starting to think the lack of an answer is telling me more.

You want an answer? Do you realize that being married to you is like being in a prison? Every hour of every day you need to be in constant contact with everybody and critiquing every aspect of their life. You thrive off of controlling other people. I've always worried what would happen when people don't meet your expectations, and I guess we've finally found out.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: Don’t change the subject, Diane…
I don’t want to be persecuted for …
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: I just want you …
… just trying to be a better …
… you keep going against the family …
… the kids don’t deserve this …
… I shouldn’t have to sit here and ...
OH MY GOD SHUT UP!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
You want an answer? Children! I’m leaving.
I need to do some thinking. I’m going to head to my mother’s house, she’ll know what to do. You and Alex are welcome to come with me.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: Can I really go with you?
See dear, even your own children don’t want to be around you.
Come on! I’m sorry for doubting you! Don’t leave me! Kids?!
It’s too late. I have had enough and the kids are done too.
Uh huh, sure. An apology is nice but it won’t erase all this pain you’ve put me through.
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: This was all for your own sake, Alex.
Not at all. This was at the cost of both Alex and my sanity.
I’ve done all this for a very good reason, you know?
The time for bullshit is over. This is literally going nowhere!
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: You think this is funny? Hell, what do you know about anything I’ve felt? You haven’t even been home for four whole years and you think you can barge back in here and you want to tell me how to feel?
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: All of us have felt this way for a very long time. Especially after your father let that damned promotion get to his head.
Yeah, and we’re sitting here being oppressed by his stupid rules.
Yes. Just hear me out, please.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Not anymore. No more of this. Your father’s had plenty of time to remedy this.
Diane! Listen to me, even if it’s just this once!
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: I am done trying to accommodate for you. Everything I’ve spent the last year doing has been for nothing, evidently.
So, I’m the problem now?
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: Wow, I knew we couldn’t rely on you, but now this? How idiotic do you have to be to not see what Dad’s done to us?
Alex! Diane! Stop this now!
Why? Don’t like being on the other end of the stick?
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: Timothy, you need to understand that we can’t possibly be happy with these silly rules you’ve set up, and how I spend my 'allowance.'
That’s how we can organize our financial situation! Have you seen how much of a mess everything was before this?

And there was never a problem. I'm sick of being treated like I'm less of a person just because my husband can't come to terms with the fact that I work well, do taxes and handle money. I'm not just going to be forced to sit at home.
Your new crystal glasses are not helping your case.
What, we can’t afford any luxury in our own home now? That’s what we’ve come to?
What do you need luxury drinking glasses for anyways?
To improve our quality of life. For those special evenings and events, of course. What’s wrong with spending for some enjoyment in life?
I just don’t think they are necessary.
Hah. Good luck with that. They’re at it again. Not that you’d know.
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: We really need to have a good chat.
All you want to do is impose on the rest of us even more. It’s like you don’t even want us around.
I have my side of the story too.
Pretty sure it’s just you confessing that you’re allergic to a happy family.
I’ve done nothing to make you all unhappy. I wanted nothing but the best for this family.
You think this is still a family? Amusing.
So I’m just talking to a brick wall here.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Nothing new to you anyways. You never cared about us.
You have the stomach to even say that?

Yes, you’re the reason we can’t live our lives how we would like. There’s nothing you’ve done that’s even made us happy. It’s all about how much you have in your savings account and how controlling you feel. Never about your own family.
You really think you’ll be happier without me here? Fine. If you say that that’s for the best, I’ll leave. Have your precious ‘quality of life’ without me.

Well, cry me a river. Do you realize how pathetic you sound? While you were off getting some dumbass college degree, I’ve been stuck here living through some episode from a garbage soap opera that no one likes to watch! Go ahead and tell me more about how hard college was. Trust me, I’d rather do all the hard shit you had to do as long as I don’t have to deal with this.
Dialogues.speaker: alex

Dialogues.content: Hey! Don’t you dare think you can just waltz in after years of being away and start running your mouth all over the place. Alex is right. Living with your dad is bad as it is and we definitely don’t need any more negativity.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: Listen to yourself! Have you no care for anyone but yourself? We’re so sorry we didn’t take some time out of our peachy lives to roll out a red carpet or something.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: I’m sorry, honey. I know you're exhausted, but we've been dealing with a lot too. It hasn’t been easy.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: We didn’t exactly wants things to be this way either, my dear. Your sister and I can’t really catch a break here either.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: You see? The world doesn’t revolve entirely around you and your fancy new degree. We’ve all got our shit to take care of.

Oh no, by all means, please do let your role model here go on Alex. Apparently we have ourselves a new head of household who thinks they're all that with their shiny college degree. No kid, That’s not how it works. You’re just one part of the family as long as you’re under this roof,  and you better learn to act like it. Didn’t they teach you that in university?
Enough! I won’t allow you to disrespect me like that. Ungrateful child. I didn’t bust my ass to get you through college so that you can come here and disrespect me.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: You better watch your tone.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: No, but you thinking we can just forget our problems just because you’re back is quite selfish.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Well you don’t always get what you want and that’s that.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: Will you two cut it out for a second? This is bad.
Yeah, thanks for a great dinner, fam.
Aw, but we were just about to bring out the graduation cake.
DAD!
Oh, shut up Timothy. Stop adding salt to the wound.
You happy now? Thanks, we really needed the extra shit today.
This is bad.
It was better before ‘‘Dr. Phil’’ walked in.
You can’t be serious.
Dialogues.speaker: mom

Dialogues.content: Oh, let it go, Diane. This circus doesn’t need any more clowns anyways. You’ll come crying back when the big, bad world hurts your feelings.
Yeah whatever. It’s not like you being here will help. He’ll just have more people to start stupid arguments with if you stick around. So bye...I guess...
Ok, that’s all I’m asking for too. Thanks for hearing me out.
Dialogues.speaker: dad

Dialogues.content: This is a stressful time for all of us, we can’t turn on each other again.

Dad, I just wanted to say that even though I haven’t really showed it, I don’t want to fight anymore. I see that I have been behaving pretty bad, but I have agreed to change that. Thank you for putting me in the Girl Scouts. Thank you for keeping me in science classes. Thank you for supporting me, in your own special way, when Mom was busy and when I was getting through school. Thank you for believing in me because you saw that I could possibly do big things. If it wasn’t for you, I don’t think I could have gotten this far. You treat us pretty… harshly, but I now see that you only want us to succeed. I’m happy that you are my Dad and I love you!
Wow, Alex… I thought I would never hear that from you. Thank you…. I love you too!
Now don’t start the water works yet, we still have dessert to get to.
Aww yes! Cheesecake! My favorite!
